answers.author: Robin Weaver
answers.text:
Additional time off and/or flexible time or a shortened work week may allow those near retirement to do some of the things they want to do in retirement without leaving the workforce.  You may want to find ways to engage them in important work, perhaps a two year project or process which would also delay their departure.  Engaging these folks in training others would be beneficial for the soon to retire, the trainees and the organization.

answers.author: Mark Abeles-Allison
answers.text:
They should look at health reimbursement accounts (HRAs).  These can be written to benefit specific groups.  Ie:  with a high deductible plan, you could include a stipulation that a percentage of the unspent high deductible could roll over to a retire health account.  If you wanted to I bet you could narrow the recepients.  For example, those with over 20 years of service, 50 percent of unspent high deductible rolls over into an employees HRA for use after retirement...

text:
An Alliance member has a high-volume of potential retirees coming up and they are looking at incentives to retain some of the retirees.  Please share your ideas, suggestions and policies to incentivize employees to continue working at the city.
